Award.AwardTitle: What is Engineering Knowledge: A Longitudinal Study of Conceptual Change and Epistemology of Engineering Students and Practitioners

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this engineering education research project is to understand the conceptual and epistemological differences between young undergraduates and early-career practicing engineers and to understand the processes that result in these differences. Past research has shown that engineering, science, and mathematics students do not understand concepts fundamental to their discipline, but researchers do not fully understand the conceptual and epistemological frameworks used by early-career practicing engineers. Since one of the objectives of undergraduate engineering education is to prepare students to practice engineering, it is essential to understand how and what practicing engineers know. This project, focused on the specific context of civil engineering, will model the development of student and early-career engineer epistemology and conceptual understanding of civil design concepts, and identify key conceptual and epistemological changes that challenge early-career engineers.

To understand how students' knowing changes as they become practicing engineers this research project is based on two external sources of foundational research:
(1) Theoretical cognitive research on conceptual change that provides extensive evidence of the value of conceptual understanding and a methodological basis for researching engineering thinking and knowing.
(2) Epistemology research that provides clear evidence of the importance of epistemology to diversity, retention and learning and a framework for understanding how engineers use knowledge differently than other disciplines.

The broader impacts of this project can directly inform engineering teaching and learning by providing roadmaps representing how conceptual change and epistemology vary across gender and ethnic backgrounds. This knowledge can help understand, and thus improve retention. To maximize the impact of this research, the results of this project will be shared with engineering educators.

The purpose of this project was to describe changes in students’ thinking as they transition from secondary education to the practice of engineering.  Drawing from cognitive science, learning science and educational psychology we tracked two elements of the participants’ thinking: (1) their conceptual understanding (CU), meaning their deep, intuitive understanding of a subject, and (2) their personal epistemologies (PE), meaning their understanding of how their own knowledge works.  Changes in the participants’ CU’s would changes in ways of thinking about the world, while changes in their PE’s would suggest changes in ways of thinking about their understanding of the world.  Our purpose was achieved through regularly interviewing two cohorts of students for three years.  The first cohort moved from sophomore to senior-level coursework and the second moved from senior-level coursework to 2 years of experience in engineering practice.  It is difficult to measure conceptual understanding or personal epistemology, and there are no surveys that are reliable and valid.  In following approximately 20 participants for three years, then, we have conducted more than 200 extensive interviews (90 minute interviews conducted twice a year to thoroughly describe participants’ conceptual understanding and personal epistemologies at that point in time) and 1500 check-in interviews (10-30 minute discussions conducted every two weeks to describe the participants’ work and coursework).  In total we have conducted, transcribed, and analyzed more than 3000 hours of interviews with students and early-career engineers.

Our research was guided by six primary questions:

  1. How do students change conceptually and epistemologically during the course of their undergraduate education?
  2. Which previous student beliefs and ways of thinking are the most resistant to change, and interfere the most with learning?
  3. How do early-career engineers change conceptually and epistemologically during the course of their first 2 years of practice?
  4. How do the changes inspired in undergraduate engineering programs help or hinder engineers through their first 2 years of practice?
  5. How do engineers use the engineering content (laws, equations, computational skills, understanding of fundamental phenomena) they remember?
  6. What conceptual and epistemological differences are there between the sociocultural contexts represented in our sample?

This study provided an unprecedented understanding of the complexity of conceptual and epistemological development.  We found that participants’ CU’s and PE’s were shaped by their workplaces and experiences, but also played an important role in shaping those experiences through the participants’ expectations and interpretations.  This suggests that any useful understanding of students’ development into engineers will require a robust way of describing these interactions between an individual and their environmental and social settings.  We have begun to develop methods to develop these descriptions.
